name: Eindhoven
fun_fact: Fun fact: Eindhoven is known as the 'City of Light' because Philips was founded here in 1891 as a light bulb company. During Carnival, the city is rechristened 'Lampegat' (Hamlet of Lamps). Fun detail: the Eindhoven train station is cleverly designed to look like an old Philips radio! PSV soccer club's stadium stands exactly where the Philips Elftal played their first match in 1911 - the only place in the Netherlands where a stadium occupies its original founding location.

hero_dishes.name: Stroopwafel
hero_dishes.description: Two thin layers of crispy waffle with caramel syrup filling in the middle
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originating from the city of Gouda in the 19th century, stroopwafels were first crafted by resourceful bakers using leftover crumbs and syrup. While you can buy ready-made versions at supermarkets, fresh stroopwafels with warm syrupy caramel are incomparable. For authentic experience, place the stroopwafel over your hot beverage for a minute, allowing the caramel to soften.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Markets like 18 Septemberplein where you'll find 'De echte goudse' (described as 'pure gold'), Albert Heijn supermarket, and specialty shops

hero_dishes.name: Bitterballen
hero_dishes.description: Small round croquettes filled with beef or veal ragout, coated with breadcrumbs and served with mustard
hero_dishes.origin_story: The name 'bitterballen' harks back to when they were commonly served with bitters, a type of alcoholic beverage. These are the quintessential Dutch bar snack, traditionally enjoyed with beer in brown caf√©s (traditional Dutch pubs).
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mathilde (offers five different types including risotto and cheese versions), Gastrobar Luzt (special pulled-pork bitterballen), brown caf√©s throughout the city

hero_dishes.name: Stamppot
hero_dishes.description: Hearty winter dish of mashed potatoes mixed with vegetables like kale (boerenkool), sauerkraut, or carrots and onions (hutspot), served with smoked sausage (rookworst)
hero_dishes.origin_story: The Netherlands' most famous comfort meal, stamppot represents Dutch resourcefulness and heartiness. Different regions have their own variations, making it a true national dish that warms you through cold Dutch winters.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Dutch restaurants and brown caf√©s throughout Eindhoven

hero_dishes.name: Hollandse Nieuwe (New Herring)
hero_dishes.description: Raw herring eaten with raw onions and pickles, considered a delicacy
hero_dishes.origin_story: The herring is caught in May or June, and its season lasts only a few weeks, making it a special seasonal treat. The first catch of the season is a celebrated event in Dutch culture.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors and fish stalls, especially during herring season in late spring/early summer

signature_drinks.name: Dutch Beer
signature_drinks.description: Local and regional beers from Dutch breweries
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed in brown caf√©s alongside bitterballen and other bar snacks. Eindhoven has several specialty beer spots including Van Moll

signature_drinks.name: Genever (Dutch Gin)
signature_drinks.description: Traditional Dutch spirit, the predecessor to modern gin
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served in brown caf√©s, often paired with traditional Dutch bar snacks

signature_drinks.name: Specialty Coffee
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Eindhoven has a thriving coffee culture with shops like Lucifer Specialty Coffee, Meneer de Boer, and CoffeeLab serving locally roasted beans. Often enjoyed with stroopwafel on top of the cup.

food_culture_notes: Poffertjes are fluffy coin-sized pancakes made with yeast and buckwheat flour, served with powdered sugar and butter
Dutch pancakes (pannenkoeken) are thin, dinner-plate-sized, and can be sweet or savory
Pannenkoekenhuis de Proeftuin in Eindhoven serves traditional pancakes
Erwtensoep (pea soup) is a hearty soup made with split peas, pork, carrots, leeks, and celery
Top food spots include RPEL, Meneer De Boer, Bagel & Beans, and DENF Coffee
Philips' green legacy makes Eindhoven one of the greenest cities in the Netherlands
Glow festival in November attracts 750,000+ visitors for light art installations
Dutch Design Week in October brings 350,000+ visitors to 120 venues
